Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, the clatter of plates and laughter filling the room. My brother nudged me, asking about my day, and my mother chimed in, eager for stories. As a sister, I knew how much these moments meant to my family—they expected me to be present, to share, to be open. But as a volunteer at the local shelter, I had just come from a shift where I’d listened to people’s stories, some light, some heavy, all private. When my aunt asked, “You must hear such interesting things—anything funny happen today?” everyone turned to me, waiting. I felt the weight of their expectation to contribute, to be part of the family’s easy conversation. But I also felt the invisible boundary of trust from those I helped, even if nothing sensitive had been said. My mind raced, torn between wanting to make my family happy and honoring the unspoken promise of confidentiality. The room grew quiet, all eyes on me, and I felt the tension coil inside, unsure which part of myself to honor.
